MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Matters. - Castleknock (Dublin) Second Level Education Needs.

Speaker.P: I thank the Minister of State at the Department of Education, Deputy Aylward, for taking this matter. I am sure the fact that the Minister of Education is not here is not an indication that she does not take this matter seriously.

The situation is the greater Blanchardstown area, and particularly Castleknock, is that the electorate felt so irate about the lack of a post-primary school that during the last general election they fielded not one but two candidates; they put forward one candidate in Dublin North and in Dublin West because that constituency is divided. This was to highlight the fact that they wanted the post-primary school which they had been promised 20 years previously and which has never been built.

This matter has a long history. A decision was made that a site and a certain type of post-primary school was not suitable. However, a small village with a population of 1,000 has now grown to a large town with a population of approximately 60,000. The facilities have not kept abreast of that growth.

MainHeading.P: There are post-primary schools in the greater Blanchardstown area and two of the community schools have a student population of approximately 1,000. Educationalists have recognised that it is not possible to provide the best type of educational opportunities for pupils whose numbers exceed 1,000. A considerable number of children are commuting from outside the Blanchardstown area and they have been able to avail of places in schools in Stanhope Street, Brunswick Street, North Richmond Street and on the Navan Road. However, this option is no longer available as the population has also grown in these areas.

Each June I receive numerous telephone calls from people who have been told that there is no place for their children in school. Fortunately, these situations are rectified by September. However, this will not continue. Pickets will continue to be placed at the Dáil gates. I know that every area makes their case for a post-primary school. I am not asking the Minister to be Solomon.

Prior to the general election, the former Minister for Education, Deputy O'Rourke, comissioned an independent report by Professor Bannon to identify the educational requirements, particularly the post-primary requirements, for the Blanchardstown and Dunboyne areas. As a result of that report, a post-primary school, which will cater for the needs of that areas, was sanctioned for Hartstown before the temporary structure was in place. There is now a prefabricated building on the site. However, by the time that school is built there will be insufficient places to cater for the needs of the greater Blanchardstown and Castleknock areas.

There are two private schools in the area, St. Joseph's Convent, Mount Sackville and St. Vincent's, Castleknock. Each time the argument is raised about the provision of a second level school in Castleknock, both of these institutions state that they will provide for the urgent need which exists. However, this has not happened and the people in Castleknock who need post-primary places for their children are unable to afford private education. I am not asking the Minister for Education to be Solomon and decide that Castleknock should have a school and Dunboyne should not, or vice versa.

When the former Minister for Education, Deputy O'Rourke, appointed the Bannon Commission and prior to the last general election, candidates from every party, particularly from the Labour Party demanded that the results of that report be made public. The Minister for Education, Deputy Bhreathnach, has not acceded to the request by the local community to make that report public. If this report substantiates the call by the local people for a post-primary school in Castleknock, then the Minister must respond. If it does not, then we can tell the people that the independent report which was commissioned does not state there is a need. The representations I have received indicate there is a need for this school.

Today in the Dublin County Council offices an action plan was presented for the extended area of Castleknock, in Porterstown and Diswellstown, where 2,900 houses will be built. A site is being reserved there by Dublin County Council for a post-primary school. Permission has also been given for a further 1,000 houses in Clonsilla. There is no post-primary school there to cater for the needs of that area. This is probably the fastest growing area in Ireland.

I am not asking the Minister of State at the Department of Education, Deputy Aylward, to give a commitment on this matter this evening. The people of the area have their own statistics to show there is a need for this school. I want the Minister to publish the Bannon report. It will prove there is a need for a post-primary school in the greater Blanchardstown and Castleknock areas. I look forward to the Minister of State's response.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Education (Mr. Aylward) Liam Aylward
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Education (Mr. Aylward)
Speaker.P: I thank Senator McGennis for raising this matter. It gives me an opportunity to clarify the position on behalf of the Minister.

There are two post-primary schools in Castleknock at present, Castleknock College and St. Joseph's Convent, Mount Sackville. Both are fee-paying schools and cater for day and boarding pupils. There has been increasing demand in recent years from local pressure groups for the provision of a non-fee paying school in Castleknock.

Over 90 per cent of pubils from the Castleknock primary schools receive their post-primary education in either St. Dominic's secondary school, Navan Road, St. Declan's CBS, Navan Road, Coolmine Community School, St. Joseph's secondary school, Mount Sackville or St. Vincent's College, Castleknock. Other post-primary schools which are attended by Castleknock pupils in significant numbers are O'Connell's CBS, North Richmond Street, for boys, and Loreto secondary school, Stephen Green and St. Joseph's secondary school, Stanhope Street, for girls.

The Department owns a site in Castleknock on which it was originally intended to build a post-primary school. The question of adequate post-primary accommodation in Castleknock is closely linked to the provision in Hartstown and Dunboyne. In August 1991, following meetings with parental representatives, the then Minister for Education, Deputy O'Rourke, commissioned consultants to assist the Department in a study to determine the need and provision for post-primary school places in the Castleknock, Hartstown, Huntstown and Dunboyne areas. During the course of the study, the local interest groups were afforded the opportunity to meet the consultants and their views were taken into account in the preparation of the report.

MainHeading.P: The findings of the study indicated that there was an immediate need for a new post-primary school in Hartstown to be followed by a new school in Dunboyne. The findings also indicated that the needs of the Castleknock pupils could continue to be met by the post-primary schools that currently cater for the majority of them. Arrangements have been made on this basis, starting with the provision of a first block of semi-permanent accommodation, to cater for 100 to 150 pupils on the site already acquired for a new second level school in Hartstown in September 1992. A further block of permanent accommodation for 850 pupils is being provided for September 1993.

It is accepted that the data relating to housing and population trends in the Castleknock area, and the capacity of neighbouring schools on which the consultants report, that is the Bannon report, was based now needs to be updated. Accordingly, a further report is being commissioned which will take account of the more recent developments in the area. In the light of the findings of this report and on the basis of the information already available, the second level needs of the Castleknock area will be further considered by my Department.
I appreciate the concern expressed by Senator McGennis in this case and we will communicate with her as soon as the Department has an opportunity to consider the report.

Speaker.P: I thank the Minister for his interest in this issue. I am reluctant to return to the communities in Castleknock and say that another study will soon be commissioned. The data which Dublin County Council has on file and the population census will indicate that the population is increasing in this area. The Minister's reluctance to release the Bannon report speaks volumes.
We will try to expedite the preparation of that report.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Matters. - Multi-Channel Television.

Speaker.P: I would like to share my time with Senator Enright.
Is that agreed? Agreed.

I welcome the Minister of State at the Department of Education, Deputy Aylward, to the House and I welcome the opportunity to discuss this issue. However, I am disappointed that the Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications, Deputy Cowen, is not present because this matter is creating conflict in north, west and south Cork.

Senator Henry has been briefed on this issue but due to another engagement cannot be here to speak on it but she wishes to record her support for the case. The case is to ask the Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications to give further consideration to the application by South Coast Community Television Group for a licence to operate a service side by side with Cork Multi-channel so as to provide a legal alternative system in the Cork area under the broadcasting Acts. The only solution to the problem is to grant such a licence and I have no doubt that the community group will meet whatever terms of reference are applied to the granting of the licence.
Recently the local authority received a communication from the Department which stated:

The basic problem with the deflector systems is that they transmit their signals in a part of the radio frequency spectrum known as the UHF broadcasting band. The physical facts are that there just are not enough frequencies available under the agreement to enable a nationwide network of deflector type systems to be established, which could bring a range of external television services to the public.

MainHeading.P: That is happening already. For a number of years both systems have been operating and I do not see why that should not continue. Following recent discussions, I want to reassure the Minister that the South Coast Community Television Group are prepared to comply with whatever regulations are laid down. It also states in the correspondence referred to that:

... unfavourable cost comparisons play a role in the controversy surrounding illegal deflector systems and in that respect like is not being compared with like. MMDS operators are required to pay an initial licence fee of £20,000...
South Coast Community Television have not been given the opportunity because they are being denied a licence.

Within the last fortnight over 1,500 people attended two public meetings in Fermoy, County Cork. A similar problem exists in west Cork. It is not good enough for the Minister to say that the basic problem with the deflector systems is that they transmit their signals in a part of the radio frequency spectrum known as the UHF band. There has been an ongoing dispute between Cork County Council, who are the planning authority, and the MMDS operator Cork Multi-channel because Cork Multichannel refused to have an independent monitoring system. They have now agreed to the independent monitoring of the radiation emissions from the MMDS system at Cork Airport and this is merely to comply with the condition of the planning permission that the emissions must be within the parameters of the licence granted by the Department.

Furthermore, in the same area of north Cork there are ten breaches of planning permission. This is not the main point I wish to make but I want to show that there are breaches by both sides. Ten beam benders that have been erected by Cork Multichannel require planning permission. They did not have permission to erect them and the county council are seeking to force them now to obtain permission.

My main point is that we want consideration to be given to the application for a licence by South Coast Community Television Group. I am told that there is nothing under the technical conditions relating to the establishment of a programme retransmission system with which they do not comply. If a licence is granted that will be the time to monitor this compliance. The relevant statutory instrument has also been carefully studied. I ask the Minister to consider this matter on these grounds.

Speaker.P: I thank Senator Sherlock for sharing time with me. I want to ask the Minister to grant a licence to Birr Multichannel TV to operate a community TV service side by side with Horizon TV Distribution so as to provide a legal alternative system in Counties Offaly and Laois and north County Tipperary under the broadcasting Acts. Birr Multichannel was set up in 1987 to provide community television for Birr, Banagher, Clara, Ferbane, Kilcormac, Kinnitty and many other areas of Counties Laois and Offaly. A wider area of Counties Offaly, Laois and north Tipperary can benefit from this excellent service, as far away as Clonaslee, Cadamstown and even Roscrea.

This multi-national viewing is provided by means of a deflector system situated near Kinnitty. Everyone in the area benefits from this quality service provided by Birr Multichannel TV at a reasonable, affordable price. The present charge is £20 per year. The Broadcasting and Wireless Telegraphy Act, 1988, makes it illegal to use the necessary apparatus to deflect signals, and it is also an offence to allow land to be used to site the apparatus. There is a fine of up to £20,000 for these offences.

MainHeading.P: The original franchise for this area of Counties Offaly, Laois and north Tipperary was awarded to Cablelink. They applied for planning permission for a 400 foot mast and then withdrew it some time later. There were no further developments and the people in the area were satisfied with the service being provided. Horizon TV has now installed an MMDS transmitter on the Radio 3 mast without planning permission as far as I am aware. I do not remember seeing a planning application. Was the franchise for this service advertised in the national or local papers so that people could tender and the franchise be awarded after fair competition?

I want the Minister to approve a licence for Birr Multichannel TV so that they can operate a legal alternative system according to the broadcasting Acts. This is a fair request. Birr Multichannel TV charge £20 a year as I am sure the Minister of State is aware. Horizon TV will charge £99 to instal the service and there will also be an annual charge of £127.50, a high charge for those on low incomes. The Minister has the power in this matter and in the interests of fair play and justice I ask him to grant a licence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Education (Mr. Aylward) Liam Aylward
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Education (Mr. Aylward)
Speaker.P: I wish to apologise on behalf of the Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications, Deputy Cowen, for his not being here this evening. I am sure that the Members of this House will appreciate that he is busy at present due to the many problems faced by one of the prominent semi-State companies. A series of meetings is taking place today and it was not possible for him to be here.

I want to thank the Senators who have raised this matter. The Minister recently dealt with the issue in some detail in the Dáil and the raising of the matter here this evening gives me an opportunity to repeat the factual position in the Seanad. Senator Enright referred to Birr and while my reply deals with Cork he will find the reply relevant.

MainHeading.P: Government policy in regard to multi-channel choice is that the licensed means of bringing such choice to the non-cabled public is through fully licensed MMDS systems. Let me stress that there are no plans to review Government policy on this issue. It is not the case that viewers in Cork are denied the privilege of multi-channel viewing by our Department's refusal to grant a licence to illegal deflector operators for the transmission of such services in the area. The simple truth of the matter is that under the Wireless Telegraphy (Television Programme Retransmission) Regulations, 1989, Cork Communications Ltd., has been granted an exclusive licence to retransmit television programme services to homes in County Cork and west Waterford.

Due to the constraints of good frequency management, the licence is exclusive and was issued after an open competition for the franchise — a competition open to even the operators of the illegal deflector systems. It is not the intention at the Department now, or at any time in the future, to license any of the so-called deflector operators in this, or indeed in any other franchise area.

I am aware that private actions, and the threat of action, taken under the planning Acts and before the High Court. have resulted in the closure of a number of illegal transmitters in the Cork region in the recent past. I am also aware from press reports of the weekend events in the Fermoy area. The fact of the matter is that the removal of transmitting equipment from Coillte lands in Fermoy over the weekend was carried out pursuant to a High Court injunction.

The Department's information is that the MMDS multichannel service is available to all those homes in the Cork region which were receiving illegal services until recently and this fact has been advertised extensively in the local press. For instance in the Fermoy region legal multi-channel service is available in the following areas: all of Fermoy town, Ballyhooley, Ballynoe, Glanworth, Glenville, Castletownroche and Kildorrery. The contention therefore that multi-channel services are not available is far from accurate. They are available and are being provided in an orderly and legal fashion in a part of the radio frequency spectrum which will not prevent or hinder the development of our own national television services in the future be they RTE, Teilifís na Gaeilge and any future national television service independent of RTE services.

Let me reiterate that successive Governments have examined this problem a number of times at length and have concluded, without exception, that it would neither be practical nor in the national interest to licence the illegal rebroadcasting or deflector systems such as those alluded to by the Senators.

The basic problem with the deflector system is that they operate in a part of the UHF frequency band which is governed by the international treaty. Under that treaty there are simply not enough frequencies available to Ireland to enable a nationwide network of deflector transmitters to be established and, at the same time, meet other national requirements such as RTE's frequency requirements.

The fact of the matter is that if the non-cabled public want multi-channel television — and all the evidence is that the vast majority of them do — then MMDS is the only practicable option open to us at present to provide it. The technical and internationally binding constraints on us with regard to the use of the radio frequency spectrum — and particularly that part of it used by “deflector” systems — are such that we believe it is not possible to legalise them. We simply do not have acces to sufficient frequencies, first to allow countrywide operation of community or deflector systems and, secondly, to give viewers in non-cabled areas something approaching the choice of television programmes available in cabled areas while still conserving frequency spectrum to meet foreseeable developments in Irish broadcasting.
Much is often made of the supposed cost differential between services provided by the properly licensed companies, such as Cork Communications Limited——

Speaker.P: Or Birr Multichannel or Horizon.

——and that provided by the illegal deflector services. Unfailingly such comparisons do not compare like with like. The transmission facility per MMDS cell can cost up to £250,000. there will be up to 29 cells throughout the country. Up to £200 or £300 worth of equipment has to be installed in each subscriber's premises. Members of the House can readily appreciate that the investment required is sizeable by any standards. The annual cost to an MMDS subscriber will approximate to the subscriber charge for the more modern cable systems installed in recent years, that is around £100 to £125 rental per annum. While the costs are dearer than deflectors, the comparisons made are invalid.

MainHeading.P: The MMDS system is an 11-channel service and MMDS operators must pay licence fees, £200,000 in advance and 5 per cent of annual rental, VAT and copyright fees — obligations avoided by the deflectors because of their illegal status. Many people complain about the installation charge of around £100 to £125 for MMDS but forget that every deflector subscriber has to have a UHF aerial installed, which in many instances costs £100 or more. In its franchise area, Cork Communications Limited has spent in the region of £3 million on its MMDS infrastructure to date and plans to spend £12 million in total. In addition, there is the very significant employment being generated in the region. The number of people employed by Cork Communications Ltd. has grown from 60 to 120 with the advent of MMDS and I understand the company has plans to employ even more in the future.

To conclude, I would say that the Department is not unappreciative of the fact that there has been some controversy about the introduction of MMDS. We also sympathise with those who have become accustomed to the illegal deflector services. Nevertheless, we counsel caution against those who pretend that there are easy solutions to this problem. MMDS provides the possibility of professional, high-quality multi-channel service on a countrywide basis, at a reasonable cost. The service is now available in Counties Dublin, Kildare, Louth/Meath, Wexford, Cork, Kerry, Clare, Galway, Sligo, Roscommon and Offaly and I understand that there are in excess of 28,500 subscribers of which 3,500 are in the Cork region.
